response.title: No-Zero Integer Sum
response.description:
No-Zero integer is a positive integer that does not contain any 0 in its decimal representation. Given an integer n, return a list of two integers [a, b] such that:

- a and b are No-Zero integers.
- a + b = n

The test cases are generated so that there is at least one valid solution. If there are many valid solutions, you can return any of them.

examples.explanation: Let a = 1 and b = 1. Both a and b are no-zero integers, and a + b = 2 = n.
Let a = 2 and b = 9. Both a and b are no-zero integers, and a + b = 11 = n.
Let a = 1 and b = 19. Both a and b are no-zero integers, and a + b = 20 = n.
Let a = 1 and b = 49. Both a and b are no-zero integers, and a + b = 50 = n.
Let a = 1 and b = 99. Both a and b are no-zero integers, and a + b = 100 = n.

driverCode.python:
import sys
import json

{USER_CODE}

# Driver code
n = int(input().strip())
print(getNoZeroIntegers(n))

response.title: Majority Element Checker
response.description: Given an integer array nums sorted in non-decreasing order and an integer target, return true if target is a majority element, or false otherwise. A majority element in an array nums is an element that appears more than nums.length / 2 times in the array.
response.functionSignature: def isMajorityElement(nums: List[int], target: int) -> bool:

examples.explanation: The value 5 appears 5 times and the length of the array is 9. Thus, 5 is a majority element because 5 > 9/2 is true.
The value 101 appears 2 times and the length of the array is 4. Thus, 101 is not a majority element because 2 > 4/2 is false.

constraints: nums is sorted in non-decreasing order.

response.title: Champagne Tower
response.description: We stack glasses in a pyramid, where the first row has 1 glass, the second row has 2 glasses, and so on until the 100th row. Each glass holds one cup of champagne. Then, some champagne is poured into the first glass at the top. When the topmost glass is full, any excess liquid poured will fall equally to the glass immediately to the left and right of it. When those glasses become full, any excess champagne will fall equally to the left and right of those glasses, and so on. A glass at the bottom row has its excess champagne fall on the floor. Now after pouring some non-negative integer cups of champagne, return how full the jth glass in the ith row is (both i and j are 0-indexed).
response.functionSignature: def champagneTower(poured: int, query_row: int, query_glass: int) -> float:

examples.explanation: We poured 1 cup of champagne into the top glass (0, 0). It is full, and there is no excess, so the glasses below remain empty.
We poured 2 cups of champagne into the top glass (0, 0). The excess liquid is shared equally between the two glasses (1, 0) and (1, 1), resulting in each getting half a cup.
After pouring 3 cups, the top glass is full, and the two glasses below it are filled completely, giving a total of 3 full glasses.
After pouring 4 cups, the middle glass (2, 1) of the row will be half full, while the outer glasses (2, 0) and (2, 2) will be a quarter full.
With such a large amount poured, all glasses in row 33 will be full.

driverCode.python:
import sys
import json

{USER_CODE}

# Driver code
if __name__ == '__main__':
    input_line = sys.stdin.read()
    inputs = json.loads(input_line)
    result = champagneTower(*inputs)
    print(result)

response.title: Count Good Strings Containing 'leet'
response.description: You are given an integer n. A string s is called good if it contains only lowercase English characters and it is possible to rearrange the characters of s such that the new string contains 'leet' as a substring. Return the total number of good strings of length n. Since the answer may be large, return it modulo 10^9 + 7. A substring is a contiguous sequence of characters within a string.

examples.explanation: The 12 strings which can be rearranged to have 'leet' as a substring are: 'eelt', 'eetl', 'elet', 'elte', 'etel', 'etle', 'leet', 'lete', 'ltee', 'teel', 'tele', and 'tlee'.
The number of strings with length 10 which can be rearranged to have 'leet' as a substring is 526083947580. Hence the answer is 526083947580 % (10^9 + 7) = 83943898.

response.title: Minimum Moves to Pick K Ones
response.description:
You are given a binary array nums of length n, a positive integer k, and a non-negative integer maxChanges. Alice plays a game where the goal is for Alice to pick up k ones from nums using the minimum number of moves. When the game starts, Alice picks up any index aliceIndex in the range [0, n - 1] and stands there. If nums[aliceIndex] == 1, Alice picks up the one and nums[aliceIndex] becomes 0 (this does not count as a move). After this, Alice can make any number of moves where in each move Alice must perform exactly one of the following actions:

1. Select any index j != aliceIndex such that nums[j] == 0 and set nums[j] = 1. This action can be performed at most maxChanges times.
2. Select any two adjacent indices x and y (|x - y| == 1) such that nums[x] == 1, nums[y] == 0, then swap their values (set nums[y] = 1 and nums[x] = 0). If y == aliceIndex, Alice picks up the one after this move and nums[y] becomes 0.

Return the minimum number of moves required by Alice to pick exactly k ones.
response.functionSignature: def minimumMoves(nums: List[int], k: int, maxChanges: int) -> int:

examples.explanation: Alice can pick up 3 ones in 3 moves, performing specific actions from the starting position.
Alice can pick up 2 ones in 4 moves, utilizing maximum changes allowed.
